mdx: A versatile container component presents self-contained information, often combining text, images, and actions, making it ideal for displaying summaries or content previews. ## Overview This versatile container component often integrates text, images, and actions. Interaction methods differ: some are clickable, others use buttons and links, and some are purely informational, grouping content without direct interaction. ### Resources Deep dive into implementation details and access the Nimbus design library. [Figma library](https://www.figma.com/design/gHbAJGfcrCv7f2bgzUQgHq/NIMBUS-Guidelines?node-id=1793-8790&m=dev) ## Guidelines Card component guidelines focus on providing a clear, concise, and visually distinct container for related content, ensuring scannability, clear actions, and adaptability across various layouts and screen sizes. ### Best practices - **Clear purpose:** Each card should represent a single, distinct piece of content or concept. Avoid combining multiple unrelated ideas into one card. - **Concise content:** Keep the information within a card brief and scannable. Use clear headings, short descriptions, and only essential details. - **Visual hierarchy:** Establish a clear visual hierarchy to guide the user's eye. Use appropriate typography, spacing, and visual cues to prioritize important information. - **Actionable elements:** If the card requires user interaction, clearly present the primary action(s) with prominent buttons or links. Limit the number of actions to avoid overwhelming the user. - **Consistent styling:** Maintain consistent styling for cards. This includes borders, shadows, typography, and spacing. - **Responsive design:** Ensure cards adapt well to different screen sizes and orientations. Consider how the layout will change on mobile devices. ### Usage The strength of using cards in a UI lies in their ability to present information in concise, digestible chunks, making it easy for users to quickly scan, understand, and interact with related content, especially in responsive layouts. > [!TIP]\ > When to use - **Displaying a collection of related items:** When you have multiple, distinct items that share a similar structure or theme (e.g., product listings, documentation, user profiles). - **Presenting scannable summaries:** When you need to provide a quick overview of information, allowing users to grasp the key details at a glance. - **Highlighting key information:** When you want to draw attention to important pieces of content or features. - **Facilitating task completion:** When a card can contain actions that allow users to quickly interact with or manage the displayed information. - **Creating a visually organized layout:** When you need to break down complex information into digestible chunks and create a structured, modular design. - **Responsive design:** When you need a component that adapts well to various screen sizes and can be easily rearranged on different devices. - **Content discovery:** When you want to encourage users to explore different pieces of content. > [!CAUTION]\ > When not to use - **Presenting linear processes:** When users need to follow a specific, sequential flow (e.g., a step-by-step form or a tutorial). Other patterns like steppers are more appropriate. - **Displaying single, detailed items:** When you need to present a lot of in-depth information about one specific item. A dedicated page is usually better. - **Primary navigation:** Using cards for main site navigation can be overwhelming and make it difficult for users to understand the site's structure. - **Simple lists:** For basic lists of items with minimal information, a simple list or table might be more efficient and less visually heavy. - **When content is highly interrelated and needs comparison:** If users need to compare specific attributes across multiple items, a table might be a better choice. - **Overcrowding the UI with too many cards:** Using too many cards on a page can lead to visual clutter and make it hard for users to focus on what's important. - **Forcing content into a card structure:** If the content doesn't naturally fit into a card format, trying to force it can lead to awkward design and a poor user experience. ### Content Content within cards should be concise and focused, prioritizing key information and clear actions to ensure scannability and quick user comprehension. Consider the card's purpose and limit content to only the most relevant details, using clear headings and short descriptions. > [!TIP]\ > **Do** > > - Cards are best for presenting self-contained pieces of information. > - Design cards with clear headings, concise text, and a logical visual > hierarchy for easy scanning. ```jsx-live const App = () => ( Discount templates Templates allow you to get started quickly and easily by displaying only what is needed for creating your discount. {/* Options would go here */} ); ``` > [!CAUTION]\ > **Don't** > > - Avoid cramming too much information into a single card. Each card should > focus on a single subject. > - Long, scrolling cards can be cumbersome; prioritize key information. > - Don't use a card to compare information. ```jsx-live const App = () => ( Discount templates Templates allow you to get started quickly and easily by displaying only what is needed for creating your discount. {/* Options would go here */} Product discount A product discount applies a percentage-off (relative) or amount-ff (absolute) discount to a specific product or subset of products before adding them to the cart. They are useful for displaying discounted or sale prices on a product info page ); ``` ### Actions Actions within a card should be limited and focused, prioritizing the primary action related to the card's content to avoid overwhelming the user. Ensure actions are clearly labeled and visually prominent to facilitate quick interaction. > [!TIP]\ > **Do** > > - If interaction is needed, provide obvious and limited actions. > - Users often assume cards are clickable, especially when they contain visual > cues that suggest interactivity, like buttons, links, or hover effects. > However, this assumption isn't universal and can vary depending on the > context and user experience. ```jsx-live const App = () => ( Learn more about products Discover what a product list is and how to manage it. ); ``` > [!CAUTION]\ > **Don't** > > - Don't use too many actions for the user within cards. > - Cards are generally not suitable for primary site navigation. ```jsx-live const App = () => ( {/* Main Card */} See your products You have modified products that are waiting to be published {/* Buttons */} {/* Bottom Row Cards */} {/* Products Card */} {/* Half width approx */} Products {/* Discounts Card */} {/* Half width approx */} Discounts ); ``` ## Properties ## Accessibility Accessibility ensures that digital content and functionality are usable by everyone, including people with disabilities, by addressing visual, auditory, cognitive, and physical limitations. ```jsx-live const App = () => ( ) ``` ### Accessibility standards #### 1. Perceivable: - **1.1.1 Non-text Content:** Provide descriptive alternative text (alt attribute) for images within cards. - **1.3.1 Info and Relationships:** Use semantic HTML to structure the card content logically (e.g., headings, lists). - **1.4.3 Contrast (Minimum):** Ensure sufficient color contrast between text and background within the card. #### 2. Operable: - **2.1.1 Keyboard:** Ensure the entire card or its primary interactive elements are focusable and operable using only a keyboard. - **2.4.7 Focus Visible:** Provide a clear visual focus indicator when the card or its interactive elements are focused. - **2.5.8 Target Size (Level AAA in WCAG 2.2):** If the card is interactive, ensure touch target sizes are adequate. #### 3. Understandable: - **1.3.2 Meaningful Sequence:** Ensure the content within the card is presented in a logical order. - **3.3.2 Labels or Instructions:** Provide clear labels or instructions for form elements within cards. #### 4. Robust: - Use semantic HTML to ensure compatibility with assistive technologies. - Avoid making the entire card a single interactive element if it contains multiple distinct actions, to ensure proper interaction for assistive technology users.
